Package tage.physics.JBullet

Class JBulletPhysicsObject

java.lang.Object
tage.physics.JBullet.JBulletPhysicsObject
All Implemented Interfaces:
PhysicsObject
Direct Known Subclasses:
JBulletBoxObject, JBulletCapsuleObject, JBulletCapsuleXObject, JBulletCapsuleZObject, JBulletConeObject, JBulletConeXObject, JBulletConeZObject, JBulletCylinderObject, JBulletCylinderXObject, JBulletCylinderZObject, JBulletSphereObject, JBulletStaticPlaneObject
public abstract class JBulletPhysicsObject extends Object implements PhysicsObject
If using TAGE, physics objects should be created using the methods in the TAGE Scenegraph class.

    • setBounciness

      public void setBounciness(float bounciness)
      Set the bounciness (restitution) coefficient. The value should be kept between 0 and 1. Anything above 1 will make bouncing objects bounce further on each bounce. The true bouncieness value of a collision between any two objects in the physics world is the muplication of the two object's bounciness coefficient.
      Specified by:
      setBounciness in interface PhysicsObject
      Parameters:
      bounciness -

    • setSleepThresholds

      public void setSleepThresholds(float linearThreshold, float angularThreshold)
      Description copied from interface: PhysicsObject
      Sets the sleep threshold for this physics object. The sleep threshold determines at what velocity an object is determined to have come to rest and thus is no longer updated by the physics engine until another object or force affects the object. This can slightly improve performance and help with object having a slight vibrating effect when they should come to rest.
      Specified by:
      setSleepThresholds in interface PhysicsObject

    • getLinearSleepThreshold

      public float getLinearSleepThreshold()
      Description copied from interface: PhysicsObject
      Returns the linear sleep threshold.
      Specified by:
      getLinearSleepThreshold in interface PhysicsObject
      Returns:
      the linear sleep threshold for this object

    • applyForce

      public void applyForce(float fx, float fy, float fz, float px, float py, float pz)
      Description copied from interface: PhysicsObject
      Applies a force with the force vector (fx, fy, fz) at local position (px, py, pz). For example, applyForce(0,10,0,0,0,0) will apply a force of 10 in the Y direction in the local center of the object.
      Specified by:
      applyForce in interface PhysicsObject
      Parameters:
      fx - the X component of the force vector
      fy - the Y component of the force vector
      fz - the Z component of the force vector
      px - the X component of the local position
      py - the Y component of the local position
      pz - the Z component of the local position

    • applyTorque

      public void applyTorque(float fx, float fy, float fz)
      Description copied from interface: PhysicsObject
      Applies a torque on the object. The torque vector direction defines the axis the objects force will be applied to and the magnitude of the vector defines the actual amount of torque. For example, applyTorque(0,50,0) will cause the object to spin with a force of 50 around the vector pointed in the Y direction using the right-handed rule.
      Specified by:
      applyTorque in interface PhysicsObject
      Parameters:
      fx - the X component of the torque vector
      fy - the Y component of the torque vector
      fz - the Z component of the torque vector
